channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Let’s do an experiment! Perl role in Canberra, Australia
item.description: Cutting-edge bioinformatics company in Australia looking for a developer with excellent Modern Perl skills (ideally with Dancer), at least some familiarity with JavaScript on the front-end, and an openness to learning new things – there’s a learning curve regarding the domain knowledge, but they’ll be happy to teach you.

item.title: Pop Quiz and Your New Perl Role! 100% Remote within UK
item.description: This is the role for you if you want start-up vibes in an established company. Not feeling the urge to commute during these socially distanced times and beyond? Not a problem. The role is 100% remote-friendly for folks in the UK. The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks.

item.title: What would your computer say about you? Perl, Python, NLP role in Amsterdam
item.description: Our client is the worldwide leader in machine intelligence for matching people with jobs, which is to say that when it comes to hiring, they know what they’re doing. They’re looking for a Natural Language Processing (NLP) Engineer who is passionate about Machine Intelligence and can evaluate NLP systems.

item.title: Let’s get SaaSsy! Remote Perl role within US time zone
item.description: Our client is the world’s leading provider of award-winning intelligent SaaS solutions for clients ranging from first responders and engineers to manufacturers and educators. The successful candidate is a Perl developer with Catalyst and Dblx::Class.

item.title: Change the world without leaving your desk! Remote Perl (or on-site) - UK, Switzerland, USA, CAN, SA
item.description: As a thriving multinational fundraising group our client works with thousands of charities to provide cloud-based management tools to connect with their supporters. These gurus of giving are seeking a mid-level and a senior Perl developer to join their team. Automated payment experience is a must-have!

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Hacker Interviews: Larry Wall
item.description: Someone on Facebook shared this interview with Larry. Just resharing with a larger audience; nostalgic.

item.title: Regexp::Grammars parse text with markup or markdown
Perl Weekly Challenge 122: Average of Stream and Basketball Points
Streams and Scores: The Weekly Challenge #121
Keeping Up the Average Number of Trips From the Line
Of Points with Raku and Perl
Perl Weekly Challenge 122: Average of Stream
Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 120
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 122
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Average of Stream" and "Basketball Points" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 123
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Ugly Numbers" and "Square Points". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: The four noisy horsemen of Perl hate
item.description: Mark continued his weekly blog fun and in this blog he discusses some good old complaints about the Perl language. It is a fun read.

item.title: IV vs PV serialisation
item.description: Felipe recently shared this post on Facebook which discusses a serious matter. Just wanted to present it to a wider section of the Perl audience.

item.title: More on monkeys and coconuts
item.description: More on the monkey and coconut puzzle. More fun and laughs.

item.title: Brute forcing "The monkey and the coconuts"
item.description: Flavio is in a puzzle mood this week. It is always pleasure to read his blog. Enjoy.

item.title: A toy RSA implementation
item.description: Although it says toy, in my opinion it is a serious talk. Thanks Flavio for sharing it with us. You made it look so easy.

item.title: Brute forcing a puzzle
item.description: Flavio came up nice little puzzle and showed the fun behind the scenes. Nice puzzle, could be a nice easy task for the weekly challenge.

item.title: Random Thought: Exposure of Perl in the Academic Circles
item.description: A very nice collection about the usage of Perl in Academic Circles.

item.title: Released Giblog 2.0, and a movie "How to create your web site using Giblog and Perl"
item.description: Announcement of the latest release of the Giblog web site creator app which is written in Perl.

item.title: #522 - Promote Perl
item.description:
Hi there

I am sure many of you are aware of Outreachy. It all started with GNOME's Women's Summer Outreach Program (WSOP) in 2006. The idea was to encourage women's participation in Open Source projects. In 2009, the GNOME community revived the program to encourage more women to contribute to GNOME and renamed it to GNOME Outreach Program for Women. It became a very popular program in no time and successfully brought in more women into the fold. The program was further expanded with more organisations joining in e.g. Fedora, Mozilla, JBoss, OpenStack, Subversion etc. With the additions, in 2013, the program was renamed to the Free and Open Source Software Outreach Program. At one point, there were 16 organizations involved in this program. In 2015, the program was again renamed to Outreachy.

Did I mention Perl in the above discussion?

Well, in 2014, TPF sponsored an internship for Pattawan Kaewduangdee to work on MetaCPAN under the mentorship of Olaf Alders as a part of the Outreach Program for Women. There is another name that caught my eye, Upasana Shukla. I came across a blog post by Upasana where she mentioned how GNOME's Outreach Program for Women helped her get into the Perl fold. If you look at the list of interns from the Indian subcontinent (India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Nepal, Sri Lanka) it is amazing. In recent years, TPF has sponsored Open Food Facts projects for Outreachy. In 2020, Areesha Tariq, from Pakistan successfully got the internship to work on the Open Food Facts project. Please check out this blog post by Areesha sharing her experience. It didn't stop there, a few weeks ago, TPF announced another intern, Rosheen Naeem, again from Pakistan, to work on the Open Food Facts project. You should check out her recent blog post about her journey. It is very inspiring.

I would like to thank TPF for supporting the Perl projects and Outreachy.

I can tell you from my own experience, we have great talent in the Indian Subcontinent. I wish more and more organisations would come forward and sponsor interns from these regions. When I started The Weekly Challenge - Perl & Raku, (a.k.a Perl Weekly Challenge), I was hoping to tap into the talent pool from this region, specially young college students. As the tagline says "You do not have to be an expert" to take part in the weekly challenge. Although we do have handful of students from Russia in the team. I am glad that, at least, we have built a platform where geeks from around the world come and share their experiences every week. Maybe one day we will have sponsors to help us reach out to young talent and bring new energy into the Perl community. Sometimes I wonder why we have never had a Perl Conference on the Indian subcontinent just like we have here in Europe and America. It shouldn't be too hard to hold one as these days everything is online. We could invite guest speakers from across the globe to address the talent in the region. Is there anyone out there willing to help us orgranise Perl Conference?

A humble request to all fellow citizens of the United Kingdom, please don't listen to Boris Johnson (Prime Minister of the UK) and keep wearing masks in public and maintain social distancing.

Enjoy rest of the newsletter until then.
